description.en: Original texts from and secondary literature about the history of international law and human rights theory in Russia are read and discussed in the seminars.
description.et: Aines toimuvate seminaride jooksul käsitletakse erinevaid originaaltekste rahvusvahelise õiguse ja inimõiguste ajaloost, samuti sekundaarkirjandust.

objectives.en: The aim of the course is to make students familar with the historical formation and present state of the theory of international law and human rights in Russia.
objectives.et: Õppeaine eesmärk on tutvustada tudengitele rahvusvahelise õiguse ja inimõiguste teoreetilise käsitluse ajaloolist kujunemist ja eripära tänapäeva Venemaal.

learning_outcomes.en: At the completion of the course, the student would be familiar with the formation of international law and human rights theory in Russia and see the impact of historical-cultural factors on the formation of international law.
learning_outcomes.et: Õppeaine läbimisel orienteerub üliõpilane rahvusvahelise õiguse ja teooria kujunemisloos Venemaal ja oskab näha ajalooliste ning kultuuriliste elementide otsest mõju rahvusvahelise õiguse ja inimõiguste teooria kujunemisele.

Possible essay/research paper topics:

1)	Scholarly works of historical figures of international law scholarship in Russia such as Martens, Taube, Kozhevnikov, Tunkin, etc.
2)	Contemporary theory of international law in Russia
3)	Russia and the ECtHR: selected aspects
4)	Russia and jus ad bellum
5)	Russia and investor-state arbitration
6)	Russia, WTO and international law
7)	International law and Russian constitution
8)	Russia's official self-image in the context of international law
9)	Russia, the UN and the UN Charta

2)	Research paper (60 %)

description.et:
Comparative International Law as Conceptual Starting Point.

Please read: 
- A.Roberts, P. Stephan, P.-H. Verdier, M. Versteeg, Comparative International Law: Framing the Field, 109 American Journal of International Law 2015, 467-474 (available in ÕIS, Study Information System).
- Russia's National Security Strategy of 31 December 2015, http://www.ieee.es/Galerias/fichero/OtrasPublicaciones/Internacional/2016/Russian-National-Security-Strategy-31Dec2015.pdf .
- L. Mälksoo, Russia and China Challenge Western Hegemony in the Interpretation of International Law, EJIL: Talk! Blog 15.07.2016, http://www.ejiltalk.org/russia-and-china-challenge-the-western-hegemony-in-the-interpretation-of-international-law/ 

Questions: 
What might be some reasons in the recent surge of interest in comparative international law (CIL) as research method and perhaps even agenda? What can we learn with the help of CIL? Are there any perils as well? Would it damage the universality of international law? What is your understanding of the universality of international law?
What is the vision of international law like in Russia's national security strategy? Can you compare it to EU's and US' attitudes to international law?
What are the common features of Russia's and Chinese concepts of international law and in what way do they differ from Western understandings?

F.F. Martens and International Law during the Tsarist Period

Please read:
Articles published in the framework of the symposium on Martens in European Journal of International Law 2014 No 3, www.ejil.org 
Questions: 
How would you characterize the discipline of international law in Russia during the late Tsarist period? Do you think Martens was more an international law scholar or diplomat? What were his contributions to the development of international law in the world and in Russia? How was Martens connected to Estonia and Livonia? What do you think of the claim of Martens that a country's concept of international law inevitably reflects its understanding of domestic law and individual rights?

Grigory Tunkin and International Law during the Soviet Period

Please read: 
G. Tunkin, Theory of International Law, translated by W.E. Butler, Harvard University Press, 1947 (available in ÕIS, Study Information System)

Questions: what was the contribution of the 1917 Russian October revolution to the development of international law? What did Soviet scholars and diplomats mean by the concept of 'socialist international law'? Was international law during the Cold war "universal" or not? What were some main characteristics of the Soviet theory and practice of international law? What was the Soviet concept of human rights like?

Watching the movie "Leviathan" by Andrey Zvyagintsev.
(The movie is 135 minutes long so please come to class already at 11:45 sharp since we'll have to start with the watching sooner than the usual beginning of 12:15.)

Russian Approaches to International Law: History

Please read: L. Mälksoo, Russian Approaches to International Law, 2015, pp 36-76. 
Questions: Did it matter for Russia's understandings of international law whether the respective scholar constructed Russia as part of Europe or as something separate, even a unique Eurasian civilization? In what periods has Russia shared the understanding of international law with Europe and in what periods not?

Russian Approaches to International Law: Theory of International Law in Post-Soviet Russia

Please read: L. Mälksoo, Russian Approaches to International Law, 2015, pp 77-146.

Questions: How are state sovereignty and human rights constructed in the Russian theory of international law? Are there different camps in post-Soviet theory of international law and how would you characterize them? What, if anything, has changed in international legal theory in Russia since the Soviet period? Is international legal theory in sync with the state practice in Russia?

Russian Approaches to International Law: State Practice during the Post-Soviet Period
Please read: L. Mälksoo, Russian Approaches to International Law, 2015, pp 147-189
Questions: What have been the main cases in the international law of peace and security (jus ad bellum) since the disintegration of the USSR in 1991? Please analyze international legal aspects of Kosovo 1999, Iraq 2003, Russia-Georgia war of 2008 and Crimea 2014. On international economic law: is WTO currently working well for Russia? What about international investment law and the respective arbitrations? How do you evaluate sanctions from the perspective of international law?

Watching the movie "12" by Nikita Mikhalkov

(The movie is 160 minutes long so please come to class already at 11:45 sharp since we'll have to start with the watching sooner than the usual beginning of 12:15; plus it will end later than usual; try to stay as long as your other commitments allow you.)

Russian Constitutional Court and the European Court of Human Rights

Please read: Mälksoo's case note on Markin (American Journal of International Law 2012) and comment on the landmark judgment of the Constitutional Court of the Russian Federation of 14 July 2015 in the European Constitutional Law Review.

Questions: How would you characterize the relationship between the Russian Constitutional Court and the ECtHR? What about the constitutionality control of judgments of the ECtHR? What is the status of judgments of the ECtHR in the Russian legal system? In the past, what was the Markin case about?

Traditionalist Philosophy of Human Rights in Russia

Please read: Orthodox Declaration of Human Rights (2006), http://www.pravoslavieto.com/docs/human_rights/declaration_ru_en.htm and Mälksoo's comment "The Human Rights Concept of Patriarch Kirill and the ROC" (2013).

Questions: In what ways does Patriarch Kirill distance himself/Russia from the secular/Western concept of human rights? Do you agree or disagree and why? Do you think religious backgrounds and interpretations play a role in the understanding of human rights in the practice? Are other, non-Western cultures indeed more traditionalist?

Russia and the European Court of Human Rights: Recent Developments

In this, final class we will focus on developments in the Yukos case in the Constitutional Court of the Russian Federation and other relevant material.
